visibility_factors: Blowing snow during the morning commute window (roughly 5–10 AM)

alert_summary.description: Cold Weather Advisory in effect through 9:00 AM EST Tuesday (2026-01-27) with very cold wind chills (around -15°F to -20°F) possible, increasing risk for frostbite and difficult conditions for bus stops/walkers.

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Rockford, MI on Tuesday 2026-01-27: this looks like a LOW-to-MODERATE snow day risk. Total new snow appears light (around 0.5" from the hourly snow shown), which is usually manageable in Michigan. However, the main issue is timing and impacts: snow starts around 3–4 AM and transitions into blowing snow from ~5 AM through mid-morning with sustained winds near 15–17 mph and gusts around 20–25 mph. That can create localized whiteout/near-whiteout conditions and drifting on open roads even without big accumulations. Temperatures stay well below freezing all day (single digits to teens) so any snow that falls will not melt, and wind chills near/below 0°F around the commute add safety concerns. If the blowing-snow visibility issues verify (especially the near-0 mi period around ~6 AM), districts could consider a delay or closure despite modest totals—particularly for rural/open areas and bus routes.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Light-to-moderate synoptic snow overnight with gusty winds producing intermittent blowing/drifting and reduced visibility around the early-morning commute, but with limited total accumulation (generally <2 inches). This often creates 'slick + visibility' hazards rather than 'deep snow' hazards.

Cold, windy morning (wind chills roughly -15°F to -20°F) accompanied by on-and-off snow showers. In West Michigan this can trigger delays/closures mainly when wind chills are extreme AND districts have many rural bus routes/exposed stops.

Post-event cold with earlier precipitation leading to refreeze/black ice risk at daybreak (especially if roads were treated late or snow showers persist). Closures tend to be more likely when freezing rain/ice precedes the cold snap.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Late January in Rockford (West Michigan) commonly features frequent light snow/lake-effect bursts and cold mornings. Districts are generally equipped for routine snow and will often stay open with light accumulations, focusing closures more on ice storms, true blizzard conditions, or dangerous wind chills.
unusual_factors: Early-morning visibility concerns: several hours flagged as "blowing snow" with visibility frequently around ~1–2 miles (and one hour showing near-zero visibility in the feed), which can matter more than the total snowfall.
Cold Weather Advisory context: wind chills around the early commute are projected near the -15°F to -20°F range, which is closer to a closure trigger than the snow totals are.
Temperatures stay well below freezing all day (high ~17°F), so any untreated/slushy spots won’t melt and can polish into slick surfaces, especially on bridges and rural roads.

local_microclimates: West Michigan snow bands can vary sharply over a few miles; Rockford can see locally higher impacts if a band sets up even when the daily total looks modest.
North/east of Grand Rapids, more open/rural stretches can drift more than in the city core, affecting bus routes and secondary roads.
infrastructure_considerations: Because Michigan districts are accustomed to plowing/treating, modest totals (~0.5 inch forecast from ~1.34 cm) usually do not close schools by themselves.
Decision leverage comes from: timing (3–9 AM), blowing/drifting reducing visibility, and the morning wind chills for students at bus stops.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Minor. Rockford’s modest elevation changes mainly affect drifting exposure on open roads rather than creating large temperature differences.

history.confidence_assessment: Overall signal for a full snow day on Tuesday 2026-01-27 is LOW-to-MODERATE. Forecast snow amount is small (about ~0.5 inch), which normally would not close Michigan schools. The stronger risk factors are (1) blowing snow/visibility during the early commute window and (2) borderline-dangerous wind chills (near -15°F to -20°F) around morning hours. This setup historically aligns more with a possible delay than a widespread closure unless snow bands overperform or road conditions/visibility deteriorate more than expected right at bus time.

safety_recommendations: Highest operational risk is the 6–8 AM window: ongoing snow + blowing snow + very cold pavement temps will outpace cleanup on neighborhood/secondary roads and at bus-stop approaches.

Prioritize plowing/salting (or treated salt/brine where effective) on bus routes, hills, bridge decks, and known drift corridors; expect re-covering/drifting after passes due to ~15–17 mph winds with higher gusts.

Plan for reduced visibility at times (forecast shows blowing snow and vis down to ~1 mile, with at least one hour near zero reported at 06:00); use slower bus speeds and increased following distance; consider holding buses if whiteout pockets occur.
Treat parking lots/walkways early (pre-6 AM if possible) and re-treat during/after the morning burst; packed snow will persist because temps stay well below freezing all day.
Cold exposure is a secondary hazard: wind chills near/ below 0°F around arrival times increase risk for students waiting at stops—shorten outdoor wait times and ensure winter gear messaging.
If considering a schedule change, a DELAY is more aligned with the forecast than a full closure: conditions are worst before/around start time and improve after ~9 AM.

MDOT/Kent County can usually keep highways/primary routes moving with continuous plowing, but the 06:30 bus-route network depends heavily on neighborhood/local streets that are typically later priority. Net: conditions look borderline-to-poor for reliable bus travel at 06:30, improving after the main snow band eases mid-morning.

Given temps around the teens and intermittent snow/blowing snow, a full snow day looks more dependent on road conditions/visibility (snow showers/blowing snow) than extreme wind chill closure thresholds. final.decision_rationale:
Pre-decision checklist synthesis:
1) Agreement: All experts agree this is NOT a heavy-snowfall event; the main risk is timing (pre-dawn through bus hours) plus slick roads and some blowing snow. All also agree a DELAY is more likely than a full closure.
2) Disagreement: The biggest conflict was WeatherAPI implying near-whiteout/very low visibility and advisory wording suggesting -15°F to -20°F wind chills. Web verification (fresh NWS update) does NOT support <= -20°F wind chills for Rockford Tuesday morning and does NOT confirm near-whiteout during 5–9 AM; safety analyst also downgraded the ‘severe’ label if vis stays ~0.5–1+ mile.
3) Plow timing math: Snow impacts ease ~09:00–10:00, which is AFTER a typical 06:30 bus rollout and AFTER a ~07:40 start. That means buses would run during the worst window; local streets likely won’t be consistently bus-ready until later morning.
4) Ice: No freezing rain signal; the ice concern is mainly packed snow/black-ice potential from very cold temps and untreated spots.
5) Neighboring districts: No confirmed Tue 1/27 closures/delays found yet on key nearby district sites; no social buzz.
6) Power: Material change—Consumers Energy shows ~33,990 outages statewide. Rockford/Kent-specific impact is unconfirmed; this adds downside risk but cannot justify a high closure probability without local confirmation.
7) Wind chill verification: Multiple web sources confirm wind chills around -2 to -4°F in the key 5–9 AM window—NOT the <= -20°F trigger.
8) What would make this wrong: If a narrow band overperforms and produces widespread near-zero visibility or fast drifted-over roads on bus routes, or if outages expand into Rockford/Kent County overnight, the closure odds jump quickly.

Weighted decision (per directive): Meteorology (25%) and Web verification (5%) pull probability DOWN because totals are light and extreme wind chill/whiteout are not confirmed. Safety (20%) and Infrastructure (10%) pull probability UP due to bus-route timing vs ongoing snow and local-street variability. News (15%) is neutral-to-down (no confirmed neighbor calls). Power (10%) pulls UP modestly due to the new statewide outage spike but with local uncertainty. History (15%) supports delay-preferred outcomes for this pattern. Net: a low-to-moderate closure chance, but meaningfully elevated above a routine 0.5–1" snow day because conditions are peaking during transport hours and local roads are the weak link.

Recommendation focus: A 1–2 hour delay is the most likely operational choice; full closure is plausible but not the base case without verified whiteout, major icing, or local outages.

alternative_scenarios.impact: Shifts buses closer to/after 09:00 when snow/blowing snow eases; improves safety on secondary/local streets and gives time to clear lots/walkways.
Higher risk for bus routes on unplowed neighborhood streets; more slip/slide incidents and late arrivals possible.

for_schools: Plan/prepare messaging and staffing for a 1–2 hour delay as the default option; make final call as close to early morning as practical with road/visibility confirmation.
Coordinate with transportation on drift-prone segments and rural connectors; consider holding buses briefly if localized visibility collapses on key corridors.
Ensure lots/walkways/entrances are treated as early as feasible and re-treated mid-morning; emphasize slip hazard mitigation due to persistent subfreezing temps.
Monitor facility power status pre-dawn; confirm backup heat/contingency plans given elevated outage environment.
for_residents: Expect slick neighborhood streets and reduced speeds during 6–9 AM; add commute time and avoid abrupt braking/turns.
Dress for cold exposure at bus stops; minimize outdoor waiting time where possible.
Charge devices and have basic outage readiness supplies due to elevated outage conditions regionwide.
for_authorities: Prioritize secondary roads feeding schools and known drift corridors before/through 06:30–08:00; re-plow where drifting re-covers lanes.
Push timely travel advisories emphasizing neighborhood street variability and school-zone approaches.
If outages are affecting Kent County, prioritize restoration for critical corridors (traffic control, public facilities) and communicate ETRs clearly.

positions.rationale: Meteorologically, this setup looks like a ‘commute-impact’ event rather than a ‘snow-load’ event. The forecast suggests light-to-locally-moderate snow showers developing pre-dawn with a several-hour window of blowing snow around start time. In Rockford/West MI, a half-inch to ~1 inch of snow usually does not close schools, but if blowing snow produces brief near-whiteout pockets on bus routes (especially rural/open stretches) right at 6–8 AM, districts sometimes pivot to a delay or (less often) a closure. Because the wind-chill extremes in the provided alerts appear less clearly supported for Rockford specifically, I weight the decision more on visibility/road impacts than on temperature alone. Net: low-to-moderate chance of a full snow day, with ‘2-hr delay’ more likely than ‘closed.’
keyFactors: Snow timing hits the decision/bus window (roughly 03:00–09:00 Tue 2026-01-27), which matters more than the full-day total.

Visibility risk is the most closure-relevant meteorological signal: multiple early-morning hours are flagged “blowing snow” with vis commonly ~1–2 miles and at least one hour modeled near zero (06:00). Even if that “0 mi” is model-noise, intermittent sharp reductions are plausible with snow showers + 15–17 mph wind.
Total accumulation looks modest (WeatherAPI totalsnow ~1.34 cm ≈ 0.5"; precip ~0.30" liquid). By itself, that’s usually manageable for West Michigan operations and argues against a full closure.

Temperatures stay well below freezing all day (teens, low single digits at night). That supports rapid glazing/packing on untreated surfaces and prevents “improvement by melting,” but it’s not a standalone closure trigger in this region.
Wind is moderate (sustained ~15–17 mph, gusts ~20–25 mph). That’s enough for drifting/blowing in open areas, but not a classic blizzard wind field.

Cross-source check suggests wind chills for Rockford Tue morning are more likely around negative single digits to low teens rather than -20°F. That reduces the odds of a cold-only closure, though cold still amplifies safety consequences at bus stops.

positions.rationale: As the HISTORY specialist, I weight how Rockford-area districts usually behave in late January: they tend to stay open with light accumulations, reserving full cancellations for heavier snow/ice or widespread dangerous travel. Tuesday 2026-01-27 has a classic *commute-window hazard* setup (03:00–09:00 snow + blowing/drifting), which historically elevates risk beyond what the ~0.5–1" snow total would imply. Still, with snow totals modest and with wind chills likely not truly extreme for Rockford itself (per the verifier), the historical analogue leans toward a **2-hour delay** scenario more than a full closure. Net: I land in the upper-20s for a full snow day, with meaningful upside risk if the blowing-snow/visibility issue verifies broadly right at bus time or if banding overperforms locally.
keyFactors: **Climatology/operational history in West Michigan:** late January districts are typically well-equipped for routine light snow; sub-1" new snow by itself rarely produces a full closure in Rockford-area districts.

**Timing matches a higher-cancellation *pattern* (pre-dawn → start-time):** precip/impacts concentrate 03:00–09:00, which is the decision + bus-route window; historically this increases closure odds even when totals are modest.

**Visibility/blowing-snow is the main “history-based” wildcard:** several hours labeled blowing snow with low vis (often ~1–2 miles and one hour near 0). Historically, brief/patchy near-whiteout during bus time is more consequential than total accumulation.

**Cold is impactful but likely not at the classic closure threshold for Rockford specifically:** multiple peers note borderline wind chills; however the web-verifier suggests Rockford’s wind chills may be closer to negative single digits/low teens rather than -20°F. That shifts history toward “delay more likely than closure.”

**Refreeze/black ice risk exists but is not a slam-dunk historical closure driver without known freezing rain/ice accretion:** temps stay below freezing all day, so any untreated moisture can polish roads, but closures in this region correlate more strongly with significant ice storms than with ordinary cold + light snow.

positions.rationale:
From a safety/operations lens, this looks like a “high-risk morning, improving after ~9 AM” day. That pattern tends to produce delays more often than full closures unless (a) the near-zero visibility hour coincides with bus roll-out across a wide area, (b) lake-effect bands overperform locally, or (c) roads pre-dawn are worse than expected on secondary/residential routes.

So I’m placing full snow-day probability in the high-20s: elevated above a routine light-snow day because of blowing-snow/visibility + persistent subfreezing pavement, but still below 50% because totals/wind are modest and the worst conditions are time-limited. If district decision culture is very cautious after the recent run of closures, that could push this up slightly; if they commonly use 2-hour delays for this profile, it pushes down.
keyFactors: Commute-window hazard is the main driver: 03:00–09:00 has active snow + multiple hours labeled “blowing snow,” with visibility frequently ~1–2 miles and at least one hour effectively near-zero (~06:00). That’s a safety risk multiplier even with low total accumulation.

Temperatures stay well below freezing all day (roughly 3°F–17°F), so any snow that falls won’t melt; slick/packed conditions persist on untreated surfaces, especially secondary/residential roads that buses use.
Wind is moderate (sustained ~15–17 mph, gusts ~20–25 mph): enough for drifting/whiteout pockets on open stretches, but not a classic blizzard wind setup.
Snow total is small (~0.5" per WeatherAPI; some sources nearer ~1"), which usually argues against a full closure in West Michigan unless visibility/road friction is notably worse than modeled.

Cold-exposure risk exists, but peer verification suggests wind chills are more like near/just below 0°F to around -10°F (not -20°F) for Rockford specifically—more likely to support a DELAY/caution messaging than force a closure by itself.

positions.rationale:
From a news/district-signal standpoint, I weight *official announcements* and *pattern-of-closures in adjacent districts* heavily. Right now, Rockford has no posted closure/delay for Tuesday, January 27, 2026, which argues against a high snow-day probability at this stage. However, the region has been actively closing schools very recently (Jan 22–23), indicating decision-makers are sensitive to hazardous winter travel and cold exposure.

Given peer inputs, Tuesday’s strongest closure pathway is not deep snow accumulation but a sharp, early-morning window of blowing snow/visibility problems and slick secondary roads for buses. That tends to produce delays more often than full closures, and it also tends to be decided late (pre-dawn). So I land at a low-to-moderate closure probability (22%), with meaningful risk still present if visibility collapses during bus hours.
keyFactors: **No official closure signal yet for Rockford Public Schools for Tue, Jan 27, 2026** (as of the news scan). That usually keeps baseline closure probability modest unless conditions are clearly extreme by late evening/early morning.

**Recent regional “closure posture” is elevated**: nearby Forest Hills and Sparta closed on Fri, Jan 23, 2026, and Forest Hills also closed Thu, Jan 22. That history raises the chance Rockford will act conservatively if Tue AM deteriorates.

**Hazard headline mismatch / alert geography uncertainty**: the provided WeatherAPI alert text mentions wind chills down to about -15°F to -20°F, but the verification summary indicates Rockford/Kent may not be in the advisory areas and independent sources didn’t show <-20°F for Rockford specifically. This reduces the odds of a cold-alone closure.

**Commute-window impacts are the plausible trigger**: multiple hours of “blowing snow” and sharply reduced visibility around ~3–9 AM (including a near-zero visibility hour in the feed) are the kind of real-time conditions that can force a last-minute delay/closure even with light accumulations.
**Snow totals look modest** (~0.5–1 inch range across sources), which in West Michigan typically points to “open or delay,” not “closed,” unless visibility/road conditions are unusually bad.

debates.challenge: Neighboring closures on Jan 22–23, 2026 show a ‘high readiness’ posture, but they were tied to different hazards (road conditions/extreme cold). Do we have confirmation those thresholds align with Tue Jan 27 conditions for Rockford specifically (not just regionally)? Otherwise it may overweight recency bias.

debates.topic: A lot of the closure-case intuition is being anchored to “-15°F to -20°F wind chills,” but the web verification suggests Rockford’s Tue wind chills may not reach that threshold. If the colder advisory wording doesn’t apply to Kent County/Rockford specifically, the historical closure rate should be dialed down and reframed toward delays driven by visibility/roads rather than cold exposure.

debates.topic: Safety assessment is (reasonably) high, but it may be implicitly treating the forecast’s near-zero visibility hour as if it will be widespread/persistent. Historically, in West Michigan, brief whiteout pockets can be highly localized; that often yields scattered delays/route adjustments rather than district-wide closure unless it’s affecting many bus corridors simultaneously.

debates.topic: Recent neighboring-district closures (Jan 22–23, 2026) are useful context, but historically they can cause ‘availability bias.’ Those closures may have been for different drivers (true extreme cold, heavier snow, or broader road impacts) than what’s forecast for Tue Jan 27. I’d avoid letting last week’s decisions over-predict tomorrow’s without matching hazard intensity/timing.

debates.topic: Be careful treating the hourly “vis = 0” value as definitive. It may be a model/artifact or a short-lived whiteout pocket. The decision-relevant question is: how widespread and persistent is sub-1/2-mile visibility between ~06:00–08:00 across bus routes, not just a single-hour datapoint.

The decision-relevant question is: how widespread and persistent is sub-1/2-mile visibility between ~06:00–08:00 across bus routes, not just a single-hour datapoint.

debates.topic: Historical closure-rate priors (e.g., 0.12–0.18) may underweight visibility-driven cancellations. This event is less about inches and more about ‘can buses safely run in drifting/whiteout pockets.’ Consider a separate bucket for “low snow, high visibility risk” mornings.

I’d de-emphasize cold-only closure logic and emphasize visibility/road impacts instead.

debates.topic: Safety rates overall risk ‘high’ and calls commute impact ‘severe.’ I agree on *operational* risk, but translating that to a *full closure* (vs delay) may be overstated given modest snow totals—unless we get verified near-whiteout pockets exactly at bus time.
debates.challenge: Safety rates overall risk ‘high’ and calls commute impact ‘severe.’ I agree on *operational* risk, but translating that to a *full closure* (vs delay) may be overstated given modest snow totals—unless we get verified near-whiteout pockets exactly at bus time.

debates.topic: History agent’s closure rates (0.12–0.22) look reasonable; my pushback is that the *recent closure streak* (Jan 22–23) can temporarily bias decisions upward, but only if Tuesday morning hazards resemble those days. Without that, base-rate should dominate.
debates.challenge: History agent’s closure rates (0.12–0.22) look reasonable; my pushback is that the *recent closure streak* (Jan 22–23) can temporarily bias decisions upward, but only if Tuesday morning hazards resemble those days. Without that, base-rate should dominate.

confidenceJourney.shiftReason: Meteorologically, this setup looks like a ‘commute-impact’ event rather than a ‘snow-load’ event. The forecast suggests light-to-locally-moderate snow showers developing pre-dawn with a several-hour window of blowing snow around start time. In Rockford/West MI, a half-inch to ~1 inch of snow usually does not close schools, but if blowing snow produces brief near-whiteout pockets on bus routes (especially rural/open stretches) right at 6–8 AM, districts sometimes pivot to a delay or (less often) a closure. Because the wind-chill extremes in the provided alerts appear less clearly supported for Rockford specifically, I weight the decision more on visibility/road impacts than on temperature alone. Net: low-to-moderate chance of a full snow day, with ‘2-hr delay’ more likely than ‘closed.’

As the HISTORY specialist, I weight how Rockford-area districts usually behave in late January: they tend to stay open with light accumulations, reserving full cancellations for heavier snow/ice or widespread dangerous travel. Tuesday 2026-01-27 has a classic *commute-window hazard* setup (03:00–09:00 snow + blowing/drifting), which historically elevates risk beyond what the ~0.5–1" snow total would imply. Still, with snow totals modest and with wind chills likely not truly extreme for Rockford itself (per the verifier), the historical analogue leans toward a **2-hour delay** scenario more than a full closure. Net: I land in the upper-20s for a full snow day, with meaningful upside risk if the blowing-snow/visibility issue verifies broadly right at bus time or if banding overperforms locally.

From a safety/operations lens, this looks like a “high-risk morning, improving after ~9 AM” day. That pattern tends to produce delays more often than full closures unless (a) the near-zero visibility hour coincides with bus roll-out across a wide area, (b) lake-effect bands overperform locally, or (c) roads pre-dawn are worse than expected on secondary/residential routes.

So I’m placing full snow-day probability in the high-20s: elevated above a routine light-snow day because of blowing-snow/visibility + persistent subfreezing pavement, but still below 50% because totals/wind are modest and the worst conditions are time-limited. If district decision culture is very cautious after the recent run of closures, that could push this up slightly; if they commonly use 2-hour delays for this profile, it pushes down.

From a news/district-signal standpoint, I weight *official announcements* and *pattern-of-closures in adjacent districts* heavily. Right now, Rockford has no posted closure/delay for Tuesday, January 27, 2026, which argues against a high snow-day probability at this stage. However, the region has been actively closing schools very recently (Jan 22–23), indicating decision-makers are sensitive to hazardous winter travel and cold exposure.

Given peer inputs, Tuesday’s strongest closure pathway is not deep snow accumulation but a sharp, early-morning window of blowing snow/visibility problems and slick secondary roads for buses. That tends to produce delays more often than full closures, and it also tends to be decided late (pre-dawn). So I land at a low-to-moderate closure probability (22%), with meaningful risk still present if visibility collapses during bus hours.

keyDisagreements.topic: Your risk level reads ‘high’ and implies ‘severe’ commute impact; from a meteorology standpoint, that hinges heavily on the single hour showing ~0-mile visibility. Can you clarify whether your conclusion still holds if minimum vis is instead ~0.5–1 mile with variability (i.e., no true whiteout), which is a common over/under in hourly feeds?

That would change my probability meaningfully.

alert.headline: Cold Weather Advisory issued January 25 at 11:07PM EST until January 27 at 9:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Ionia; Clinton; Allegan; Barry; Eaton; Ingham; Van Buren; Kalamazoo; Calhoun; Jackson
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills as low as 20 below expected.

* WHERE...Calhoun, Clinton, Eaton, Ingham, Ionia, Jackson, Allegan,
Barry, Kalamazoo, and Van Buren Counties.

* WHEN...From 7 PM Monday to 9 AM EST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 20 below zero
could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30 minutes.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Winds will increase to 15 to 25 mph Monday
night as temperatures drop into the single digits. The combination
of cold temperatures and increasing winds will drive wind chill
readings into the -15 to -20 range.
alert.instruction:
Use caution while outdoors. Wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and
gloves.

alert.headline: Cold Weather Advisory issued January 26 at 2:43AM EST until January 27 at 9:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Ionia; Clinton; Allegan; Barry; Eaton; Ingham; Van Buren; Kalamazoo; Calhoun; Jackson
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills as low as 20 below expected.

* WHERE...Calhoun, Clinton, Eaton, Ingham, Ionia, Jackson, Allegan,
Barry, Kalamazoo, and Van Buren Counties.

* WHEN...From 7 PM this evening to 9 AM EST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...The cold wind chills as low as 15 below zero could
result in hypothermia or frostbite if precautions are not taken.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Winds will increase to 15 to 25 mph Monday
night as temperatures drop into the single digits. The combination
of cold temperatures and increasing winds will drive wind chill
readings into the -15 to -20 range.
alert.instruction:
Use caution while outdoors. Wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and
gloves.

alert.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 25 at 9:44PM EST until January 26 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Snow expected Monday. Total snow accumulations 3 to 6
inches.

* WHERE...Allegan and Ottawa Counties.

* WHEN...From 1 AM to 7 PM EST Monday.

* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will
likely become slick and hazardous. Visibility and road conditions
may change rapidly over short distances in lake effect snow.
alert.instruction:
During lake effect snow, the weather can vary from bands of locally
heavy snow to dry weather just a few miles away. Visibilities can
also vary greatly. Be prepared for rapid changes in weather,
visibility, and road conditions.

alert.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 26 at 2:43AM EST until January 26 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Snow. Snow accumulations between 1 and 4 inches.

* WHERE...Allegan and Ottawa Counties.

* WHEN...Until 7 PM EST this evening.

* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will
likely become slick and hazardous. Visibility and road conditions
may change rapidly over short distances in lake effect snow.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Highest accumulations will be found towards
the lakeshore, especially from Holland south through Saugatuck,
Glenn and Pullman.
alert.instruction:
During lake effect snow, the weather can vary from bands of locally
heavy snow to dry weather just a few miles away. Visibilities can
also vary greatly. Be prepared for rapid changes in weather,
visibility, and road conditions.

alert.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 25 at 4:08PM EST until January 26 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Flooding along the Muskegon River remains possible due to
an ice jam.

* WHERE...A portion of west central Michigan, including the
following county, Newaygo.

* WHEN...Until 700 PM EST Monday.

* IMPACTS...Low lying areas along the Muskegon River that are prone
to flooding may see rapidly changing water levels.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 406 PM EST, An ice jam was reported by local authorities
on the Muskegon river in southern Newaygo County. The river
gauge at Newaygo shows water levels remaining at minor flood
stage as of Sunday afternoon.
- As the river freezes up, ice can restrict the flow of the
river and cause rises and falls in water level. Flooding due
to freeze-up ice jams is typically minor, but can be
unpredictable.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
alert.instruction:
Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law
enforcement and request they pass this information to the National
Weather Service when you can do so safely.
